Articles.Content:
Here's a lander and lifter for Eve that you refuel on the surface. 

Trying to land it full makes it likely to crash on landing and also means more mass to haul to Eve. 

![jzyWqiy.jpg](http://i.imgur.com/jzyWqiy.jpg)

Landing is with just the 1st stage tanks 50% fueled for de-orbit and to help with the last few feet of landing, the rest of the tanks are empty. 

Air brakes are deployed during re-entry to help slow down and prevent the worst of the over-heating. 

The escape tower is ejected after landing, along with it's air-brakes and 'chutes. 

Make sure you have a good engineer on-board and have done an orbital scan of Eve previously.

Start mining: Turn on the fuel-cells. Alternate between the drill and the ISRU to make LF+O. 

When the tanks are all topped off its time to launch. It will make 100km orbit from sea-level OK but any additional launch altitude will provide a safety dV margin. 

Right after lighting the first stage, decouple all the mining stuff. 

MJ can get it to orbit if you are feeling lazy: Turn start alt 10km, turn end alt 90km, final angle 1Ã‚Â°, shape 90% (yes, really).

Craft file: [https://www.dropbox.com/s/7tkjq5ww5qiswzm/Eve%20lifter%209.craft?dl=0](https://www.dropbox.com/s/7tkjq5ww5qiswzm/Eve%20lifter%209.craft?dl=0)

> 
> Interesting use of airbrakes.

It is actually surprisingly effective to use them to orient an aircraft.

Foxter, very interesting that you refuel on the surface. Pretty smart too. What is the DV requirement for Eve orbit now? Looks like a pretty small ship.

> 
> What is the DV requirement for Eve orbit now? Looks like a pretty small ship.

This craft has atmos/vac 2219/8251 dV (according to MJ) at launch with all the landing stuff decoupled. From sea-level, it makes a 100km orbit with a few hundred dV left over. 
So, the dV requirement is considerably less than with 0.9 where you would have needed (IIRC) closer to 12000 dV. 

The 'secrets' are to punch through the low level atmosphere as quickly as possible (a high TWR in the first stage) and to make sure that the engines you use have a useful TWR at the altitudes they will burn at (you can use Engineer Redux to check that).
